data.text: Where Should I Put the Bear Spray When I Bikepack?

Doing my first bike pack soon. I was wondering where others place their bear spray? I am used to having it very accessible when backpacking but not sure the best place when bike packing. I tried my morning commute with it attached to the handle bars and it seems to okay but jostles around a bit. What do you do?

I put mine in my frame pack. I put it on my bars on my first trip, but it got dented and I was afraid it would burst and mess me up good. I don’t seen a scenario where I won’t have plenty of time to open my frame pack and use it.
data.author: Drew Van Patter

data.text: yeah I was thinking that too. I think I might be leaning towards frame bag now.
data.author: Spencer Dunphy

data.text: no, bears aren't gonna time out for you to dig it out..our... that's plain foolish
data.author: Clay Gentillon

data.text: if a bear sees me and reaches me before I see it, and before I have a chance to unzip a bag and grab my spray (5-10 seconds), I’m fucked anyway. I’m not wearing it on a holster.
data.author: Drew Van Patter

data.text: ya Im not keen to have it strapped around me at all times
data.author: Spencer Dunphy

data.text: a bear can cover 50 yards in 5 seconds
data.author: Ronnie Cole

data.text: so can I when I’m cycling.
data.author: Drew Van Patter

data.text: No bears in Scotland
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: they couldn’t stand the midges!
data.author: Mark Bardsley

data.text:
I have a pack northwest hey bear, bear spray holder and attach to my handlebars. That way I don’t have to go looking for it. http://packnw.com/all-products/hey-bear-holster
Hey Bear Holster — Pack Northwest
packnw.com
data.author: Kimberly Much

data.text: If your in bear country keep it on your person... scat belt makes a good option. If it's stowed in a pack you won't have time to deploy it. And if it's on your bike while you step away it won't do you any good. Keep it on you
data.author: Clay Gentillon

data.text:
I mount it on my handlebars with in a Mystery Ranch bear spray holder which retains the canister with a shock cord based mechanism. The holder itself is mounted with a voile strap. https://www.rei.com/product/202677/mystery-ranch-bear-spray-holster
MYSTERY RANCH Bear Spray Holster | REI Co-op
rei.com
data.author: Dean H. Saxe

data.text: oh that’s a cool product. I have a case like that but it doesn’t have anything to stop it from bouncing out like this one. Thanks for the advice
data.author: Spencer Dunphy

data.text: the spray didn’t move a bit on a rough descent where I lost a knife that was clipped into a feed bag. The shock cord holder gives me the confidence that the canister isn’t going anywhere unless I want it to.
data.author: Dean H. Saxe

data.text: There’s a Great Divide route group - they obviously encounter a lot of bears. Ask there. My two pennies would be somewhere instantly accessible - no fiddling with zips. https://www.facebook.com/groups/825014527629477/?ref=share
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: Ps from posts I’ve read on it there are various opinions and solutions. I’d try a shake down ride with whatever you go with.
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: I wear a Fanny pack that has a bottle holder and I put it there. Super accessible.
data.author: Marcy Kelley

data.text: Yeah or a hydration vest if you use - keeping it on one of the shoulder straps (in bottle holder or holster) might be a great option. Think they do neoprene covers if you worry about it bursting.
data.author: Patrick Thomas Hussey

data.text: I always have two cans of bear spray on me while riding. Not just bike packing since I live in Anchorage, and you can run into bears anywhere. I use a Revelate Feed Bag attached to my handlebars to hold one of the cans. That is my quick access while I am on the bike can. I also keep a second can in my pack; always have a pack with me. While bikepacking it is where I carry my camera gear. While out just riding it is where I keep my tools and whatnot (normally, on daily rides, it is a small Camelbak, unless I am also bringing camera gear). The can on the pack is for when I am off the bike or for after a crash I get separated from my bike and have a bear encounter (especially if it was a bear that caused the crash).
data.author: Ronnie Cole

data.text: bibs with side pockets like the rapha adventure cargo bibs
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: https://www.counterassault.com/media/catalog/product/cache/12/thumbnail/1250x1250/9df78eab33525d08d6e5fb8d27136e95/1/5/157ccf56843eb869965cb865f7a5cee5.jpg
data.author: Paul Johnson

data.text: Stuck mine in the side pocket of my Ortleib QR Handlebar bag. A chuck bucket would work well too.
data.author: John Sandlin

data.text: I have a similar bag but doesn’t have the right kind of bag. Think I will lash it on somehow. Thanks for or the advice
data.author: Spencer Dunphy

data.text: Chuckbuck has my vote.
data.author: William Murray

data.text: I would guess that towards the bear would be a good idea... 😝
data.author: Guy Lawrence

data.text:
I sewed some straps on an old chalk bag, so that hangs on my handlebars. Bear spray goes in that, with the cord lock to keep it from falling out. If I’m going somewhere away from my bike, it would be pretty simple to wear the bag on a belt or string around my waist. Similar to a feed bag like this one: https://radpowerbikes.ca/products/handlebar-bag
Handlebar Bag | Rad Power Bikes Canada
radpowerbikes.ca
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: I wear a small backpack, with a water bladder inside. I spray paint the bear/(aggressive people) Spray flat black so it can’t be easily identified by those who we don’t speak their name(s). I then attach it the front of my right back strap. This way I can be braking with my rear brake while using my left hand to draw and spray. Used twice on bears, worked great, but the sound is loud enough to scare a bear too. I’ve been sprayed 4 times once on purpose, my son was sprayed as part of military training so I said I’ll try that”. Once bear and me, once by accident- orange face mess and once trying to figure out how I sprayed my self accidentally, faulty valve. By the time I was sprayed the 4th time it’s not that bad. Practice the brake and ready to spray.
data.author: Dick Blomshield

data.text: Where do you go that you actually had to use the stuff on a bear?
data.author: Douglas Kaup

data.text: Bear war eating acorns Sept. 2021. This is CT, other spot was in the ADKs of NY.
data.author: Dick Blomshield

data.text: Ask a local bear to carry it for you He can run alongside you has you pedal Than when needed he can hand it to you!
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: A racer in the Tour Divide this year was severely injured when his bear spray got jostled on his handle bars and temporarily blinded him, causing him to crash. Wherever you carry it, make sure an accidental discharge will not be directed at your face.
data.author: Andy Simmons

data.text: oh jeez. Scary
data.author: Spencer Dunphy

data.text: I have a stem / bar mounted feedbag which normally holds an extra water bottle and some snacks. The bear spray gets swapped in as needed.
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: If it's something you might need in a hurry, carry it on yourself. Something you'll, have time to get, bungee it to the top of your bags. I keep all spray on my person. Only needed pepper spray once and it was on my bike handlebars, was not able to get to it in an emergency.
data.author: Matt Fisher

data.text: Carry it on yourself.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: Attached to the top tube and on my hip when off the bike.
data.author: Alan Leopold
